current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To promote minimum State requirements for the prevention and treatment of concussions caused by participation in school sports, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

short-title.#text: Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

term.#tail: ), enact legislation or issue regulations establishing the following minimum requirements:

text.#text: Each State that receives funds under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and does not meet the requirements described in this section, as of the date of enactment of this Act, shall, not later than the last day of the fifth full fiscal year after the date of enactment of this Act (referred to in this Act as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965

header.#text: Local educational agency concussion safety and management plan

text.#text: Each local educational agency in the State, in consultation with members of the community in which such agency is located, shall develop and implement a standard plan for concussion safety and management that—
educates students, parents, and school personnel about concussions, through activities such as—

training school personnel, including coaches, teachers, athletic trainers, related services personnel, and school nurses, on concussion safety and management, including training on the prevention, recognition, and academic consequences of concussions and response to concussions; and
using, maintaining, and disseminating to students and parents—
release forms and other appropriate forms for reporting and recordkeeping;
treatment plans; and
prevention and post-injury observation and monitoring fact sheets about concussion;

encourages supports, where feasible, for a student recovering from a concussion (regardless of whether or not the concussion occurred during school-sponsored activities, during school hours, on school property, or during an athletic activity), such as—
guiding the student in resuming participation in athletic activity and academic activities with the help of a multi-disciplinary concussion management team, which may include—
a health care professional, the parents of such student, a school nurse, relevant related services personnel, and other relevant school personnel; and
an individual who is assigned by a public school to oversee and manage the recovery of such student; and
providing appropriate academic accommodations aimed at progressively reintroducing cognitive demands on the student; and
encourages the use of best practices designed to ensure, with respect to concussions, the uniformity of safety standards, treatment, and management, such as—
disseminating information on concussion safety and management to the public; and
applying uniform best practice standards for concussion safety and management to all students enrolled in public schools.

Each public elementary school and each public secondary school shall post on school grounds, in a manner that is visible to students and school personnel, and make publicly available on the school website, information on concussions that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: is based on peer-reviewed scientific evidence (such as information made available by the
shall include information on—
the risks posed by sustaining a concussion;
the actions a student should take in response to sustaining a concussion, including the notification of school personnel; and
the signs and symptoms of a concussion; and
may include information on—
the definition of a concussion;
the means available to the student to reduce the incidence or recurrence of a concussion; and
the effects of a concussion on academic learning and performance.

If an individual designated from among school personnel for purposes of this Act suspects that a student has sustained a concussion (regardless of whether or not the concussion occurred during school-sponsored activities, during school hours, on school property, or during an athletic activity)—
the student shall be—
immediately removed from participation in a school-sponsored athletic activity; and
prohibited from returning to participate in a school-sponsored athletic activity—
on the day such student is removed from such participation; and
until such student submits a written release from a health care professional stating that the student is capable of resuming participation in school-sponsored athletic activities; and
the designated individual shall report to the parent or guardian of such student—

any information that the designated school employee is aware of regarding the date, time, and type of the injury suffered by such student (regardless of where, when, or how a concussion may have occurred); and
any actions taken to treat such student.

If a student has sustained a concussion (regardless of whether or not the concussion occurred during school-sponsored activities, during school hours, on school property, or during an athletic activity), before such student resumes participation in school-sponsored athletic activities, the school shall receive a written release from a health care professional, that—
states that the student is capable of resuming participation in such activities; and
may require the student to follow a plan designed to aid the student in recovering and resuming participation in such activities in a manner that—
is coordinated, as appropriate, with periods of cognitive and physical rest while symptoms of a concussion persist; and
reintroduces cognitive and physical demands on such student on a progressive basis only as such increases in exertion do not cause the reemergence or worsening of symptoms of a concussion.

text.#text: Prior to reducing any funds that a State receives under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: in accordance with this subsection, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965

text.#text: Nothing in this Act shall be construed to affect civil or criminal liability under Federal or State law.
In this Act:

term.#tail: means a type of mild traumatic brain injury that—

text.#text: The term
is caused by a blow, jolt, or motion to the head or body that causes the brain to move rapidly in the skull;
disrupts normal brain functioning and alters the mental state of the individual, causing the individual to experience—
any period of observed or self-reported—
transient confusion, disorientation, or impaired consciousness;
dysfunction of memory around the time of injury; or
loss of consciousness lasting less than 30 minutes; or
any 1 of 4 types of symptoms, including—
physical symptoms, such as headache, fatigue, or dizziness;
cognitive symptoms, such as memory disturbance or slowed thinking;
emotional symptoms, such as irritability or sadness; or
difficulty sleeping; and
can occur—
with or without the loss of consciousness; and
during participation in any organized sport or recreational activity.
The term
means an individual who has been trained in diagnosis and management of traumatic brain injury in a pediatric population; and
includes a physician (M.D. or D.O.) or certified athletic trainer who is registered, licensed, certified, or otherwise statutorily recognized by the State to provide such diagnosis and management.

term.#tail: have the meanings given such terms in

text.#text: The terms

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:9101

term.#tail: means individuals who provide related services, as defined under

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 602 of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act

text.#text: The term
any physical education class or program of a school;
any athletic activity authorized during the school day on school grounds that is not an instructional activity;
any extracurricular sports team, club, or league organized by a school on or off school grounds; and
any recess activity.
